name: methylcyclohexane production | methylcyclohexane | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/5838/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of methylcyclohexane by hydrogenation of toluene in the presence of Raney nickel catalyst.. ;Methylcyclohexane (CAS-No. 108-87-2, C7H14, Synonyms: hexahydrotoluene, cyclohexyl methane) is a colorless transparent liquid with a faint, benzene-like odor. The primary use of methylcyclohexane is as a component in the feed to catalytic naphtha reformers where it is readily dehydrogenated to toluene, a high-octane motor gasoline component. Some methylcyclohexane is used for solvent applications in which it is one component of a narrow boiling range fraction of naphtha, but no current market exists for large-scale quantities.;In this dataset, the raw material inputs, and process-specific material exchanges, are modelled with a generic stoichiometry-based tool, using literature or estimated yields. The emissions are modelled with a default value, which is estimated based on losses, unreacted chemicals, among others. At the same time, the energy consumption is based on data from literature sources. Finally, the auxiliary (i.e., cooling water and infrastructure) exchanges are modelled with a default value based on industry data from literature sources. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;References:;Sutter, J. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Petrochemical Solvents. ecoinvent report No. 22. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Campbell, M. L. 2011. Cyclohexane. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

The activity ends with methylcyclohexane being ready for further transformation or transportation at the production site gate. Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period spans from the earliest year from which at least one of the input values was obtained until 2022, but overall form the most realistic picture of the production. Besides, the activity is partly generated, in terms of material inputs and outputs, based on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields, which does not expect to change over time.;The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989 and 1994) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. The end time period is therefore set based on the years from Gendorf reference.;For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure and in the comments of the exchanges.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989);Wurster, R., Zittel, W.: Hydrogen Energy in: "Energy technologies to reduce CO2 emissions in Europe: prospects, competition, synergy", Conference Proceeding of the Conference held at Petten, 11-12 April 1994, OECD/IEA, Paris 1994
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe. The main material inputs and outputs of this activity are generated with on a generic stoichiometry-based model, using literature or estimated yields.  Furthermore, the source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information on the calculations refer to the sampling procedure.;The dataset could also be considered as not geography-specific, and thus, valid for a broader geographical coverage.;References:;Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit ;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989);Wurster, R., Zittel, W.: Hydrogen Energy in: "Energy technologies to reduce CO2 emissions in Europe: prospects, competition, synergy", Conference Proceeding of the Conference held at Petten, 11-12 April 1994, OECD/IEA, Paris 1994
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset represents the hydrogentation of toluene. The hydrogentation of toluene is similar to the hydrogenation of benzene, with a yield of 95%. (Ullmann 2004). At the same time, the catalyst assumed is Raney nickel (50 % Ni, 50 % Al). As there was no data available for the heat requirments of the methylcyclohexane production, the values were estimated with data for the production of cyclohexane from the hydrogenation of benzene (Chauvel et al. 1989). At the same time, the electricity requirments of the toluene hydrogenations are based on the methylcyclohexane production of a plant in Germany (Wurster 1994).;Hydrogenation of toluene:;C7H8 + 3H2 --> C7H14;In this dataset, a yield of 95% was assumed.;References:;Ullmann's encyclopedia of industrial chemistry (2004).;Wurster, R., Zittel, W.: Hydrogen Energy in: "Energy technologies to reduce CO2 emissions in Europe: prospects, competition, synergy", Conference Proceeding of the Conference held at Petten, 11-12 April 1994, OECD/IEA, Paris 1994.;Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature data and stoichiometric calculation. This inventory is partially based on a generic model of the production of chemicals. The data generated by this model have been improved with compound-specific data when available. The model of the production of chemicals is using specific industry or literature data wherever possible and more generic data on chemical production processes to fill compound-specific data gaps when necessary. The basic principles of the model have been published in literature (Hischier, 2005). The model has been updated and extended with newly available data from the chemical industry. In the model, unreacted fractions are treated in a waste treatment process, and emissions reported are after a waste treatment process that is included in the scope of this dataset. For volatile reactants, a small level of evaporation is assumed. Solvents and catalysts are mostly recycled in closed-loop systems within the scope of the dataset and reported flows are for losses from this system.
The source of information for the heat and electricity inputs is literature data (from 1989 and 1994) for the specific technology. Finally, the main source of information for the values for water (process and cooling), nitrogen, and chemical factory is industry data from the GENDORF Chemical Park. The values are a 5-year average of data from 2015 to 2019 published by the GENDORF Chemical Park, which is based in Germany and produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances in the years 2015-2019. For more information refer to the comments of the exchanges.

References:
Hischier, R. (2005) Establishing Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals Based on Differing Data Availability (9 pp). The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, Volume 10, Issue 1, pp 59-67. 10.1065/lca2004.10.181.7 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit 
Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989)
Wurster, R., Zittel, W.: Hydrogen Energy in: "Energy technologies to reduce CO2 emissions in Europe: prospects, competition, synergy", Conference Proceeding of the Conference held at Petten, 11-12 April 1994, OECD/IEA, Paris 1994

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The average ouput of wastewater going to an external wastewater treatment plant in the years 2015-2019 was 5608 m3 per year. This equals 0.000002277 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description: Calculated losses, based on the boiling point of a chemical, to water or to air. In addition, unreacted chemicals are assumed to go to wastewater treatment, which has a conversion rate in biological treatment of 95% of carbon into carbon dioxide. The remaining 5% are released as emissions to water.

flow.name: Toluene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. To determine the emissions of water to air, the difference of all water inputs (from river, well, tap water and cooling) and outputs (wastewater, emissions to water) was calculated. The average ouput of water to air in the years 2015-2019 was 3620444 m3 per year. This equals 0.00147 m3/kg chemical produced. For more information on the other water exchanges please consult the respective exchange comment. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

exchanges.description:
This value is estimated based on the cooling requirements of a similar process. Specifically, this value represents the hydrogenation of benzene, which was reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989). The value of cooling water input for the latter process is 0.0035 m3 per kg.

At the same time, the latter amount was split between the following sources (1) "Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin", (2) "Water, river", and (3) "Water, well. in ground"

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: This value is estimated based on the heating requirements of a similar process. Specifically, this value represents the hydrogenation of benzene, which was reported by Chauvel, Alain, Gilles Lefebvre, and L. Castex in "Petrochemical processes. Technical and economical characteristics Vol. 2." (1989) for the liquid phase process in presence of Raney nickel catalyst. The steam input of 0.08 kg per kg are required at medium pressure, while low pressure steam is go-generated amounting to 0.95 kg per kg that could potentially recovered. All in all, we assume that the heating requirements for the hydrogenation of toluene and benzene are similar.

flow.name: Water, well, in ground
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the GENDORF Chemical Park. The factory produced an average of 2462760 tonnes of chemical substances (including intermediates) per year in the years 2015-2019. The amount of water released back to the environment consists of the sum of the amount of process water treated in the internal WWTP that is then released back to the environment and the amount of cooling water released back to the environment. The average ouput of the internal WWTP in the years 2015-2019 was 2628800 m3 and that of cooling water released back to the environment was 34408800 m3. This gives a yearly average of 37037600 m3 emissions of water to water. This equals 0.01504 m3/kg chemical produced. References: Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2016, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2017, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit Chemiepark GENDORF, Umwelterklärung 2020, https://www.gendorf.de/Nachbarn/Umweltschutz/Industrie%20und%20Nachhaltigkeit

This value represents the electricity input of methylcyclohexane production of a plant in Germany.

flow.name: BOD5, Biological Oxygen Demand
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/surface water

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. References: Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
